Dear Mr. Nolan:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
6/6-6/16/2022. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the
MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616)204-6992.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12205 Required staff.
(8) An agency shall employ or contract for a sufficient number of
competent staff to carry out the provisions covered by these
rules. The workload for each staff member shall not be more
than any of the following:
(b) Fifteen children assigned to a social services worker for
purposes of providing direct services in foster care, independent
living, adoption, or post adoption services or a combination
thereof.
The agency has not been able to maintain caseload compliance due to not being
fully staff combined with unexpected staffing changes. At the time of the inspection,
3 staff were out of caseload compliance.
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(b) Verification of education.
1 of 7 staff files reviewed did not contain the required education verification.
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(d) Three references obtained from persons who are unrelated
to the staff person.
2 of 7 staff files reviewed did not contain documentation that all references were
obtained prior to hire.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
4

1 of 6 open foster home files reviewed contained a renewal assessment that was not
completed and provided to the department 15 days or more before the license
expiration.
R 400.12325 License recommendation.
(3) Except for an original license, an agency shall recommend to
the department the issuance of a regular license or the
continuation of an active license only when all rules are in
compliance or both of the following conditions exist:
(a) All non-compliances relating to the recommendation are
correctable.
(b) A written corrective action plan has been developed. The
plan shall be in compliance with all of the following
requirements:
(i) Specify the methods, the persons responsible, the time
frames for correction; methods for ensuring the safety of any
children placed in the home; how continuing compliance will be
maintained once compliance is achieved; consequences if the
corrective action plan is not completed; and what documentation
will be required to demonstrate compliance or completion.
(ii) Require that the corrective action be completed within
six (6) months of being signed.
(iii) Be signed and dated by the foster parent and the
agency.
1 of 6 open foster home files reviewed contained an annual assessment which
documented that the family did not practice their emergency procedures once every
four months; however, the family was found to be in full compliance with no CAP
required.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(a) Submit a special investigation record to the department's
licensing authority within 5 working days in the manner
prescribed by the department.
1 of 2 special evaluations reviewed documented that the required paperwork was
not provided to the department timely.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(c) Conduct a thorough investigation including all necessary
collateral contacts.
5

1 of 2 special evaluations reviewed documented that the foster parent was not
notified that they could have a person of their choice present for the investigation.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(2) An agency shall inform foster parents of all of the following
before they are questioned or interviewed regarding a special
evaluation:
(c) That the foster parents may involve a person of their
choice in any interviews with them involving the special
evaluation if the involvement does not impede the timely
completion of the evaluation.
1 of 2 special evaluation reviewed did not document a thorough investigation of the
allegation.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a
greater frequency is medically indicated:
(ii) For a child 2 years of age or older, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 12 months before
placement or a new physical examination shall be completed
within 30 calendar days after placement.
1 of 9 open foster care case files reviewed contained an initial medical examination
completed outside of the required timeframe.
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child:
(a) Child's name.
(b) Child's date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child's health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors relating to the
care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or replacement of
the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster parent to
provide a stable, safe, and healthy environment for the foster
child and the foster family, including information about siblings
who do not reside in the foster home.
6

3 of 9 open foster care case files reviewed did not contain documentation that all
information required within subsection a-h of this rule was provided to the caregivers
within the timeframes outlined within the rule.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
1 of 12 total open case files reviewed (9FC, 3IL) contained one late initial service
plan.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
1 of 12 total open case files reviewed (9FC, 3IL) contained one late updated service
plan.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal 8/27/2020, CAP approved 8/28/2020
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(1) There shall be a mutually agreed upon contract between the
youth and the agency specifying all of the following:
(a) The responsibilities of the agency and the youth.
(b) A plan for education or work.
(c) An agreement for the youth to meet with the worker at
least one time per calendar month.
(d) The location where the youth is living.
1 of 3 files reviewed of youth in independent living placements did not contain the
required contract which would document the requirements of subsections a-d.
R 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a written
adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family signing
an adoption application and prior to approving a family for
adoption.
1 of 4 adoption files reviewed contained family assessment which was not
completed within the required timeframe.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there are

compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.

PA 116 Confidentiality
722.120.10.3
Except as otherwise provided in this subsection and subsection
(4), records regarding children and facts compiled about
children and their parents and relatives are confidential and
disclosure of this information shall be properly safeguarded by
the child care organization, the department, and any other entity
in possession of the information.
1 of 2 special evaluations reviewed identified participation of CPS-MIC in the

ADM 980 ADOPTION CLOSING SUMMARY (DHS-222)
A copy of the closing summary must be sent within 14 calendar
days of the adoption finalization date to the foster care worker
and the Department of Health and Services (DHHS) adoption
monitor for purchase of service cases for inclusion in the child’s
permanent record. The DHS-222, Adoption Closing Summary
must be used for this purpose.
3 of 4 finalized adoption cases reviewed did not contain all documents completed as
required. All three files were missing the required closing letter (DHHS 607) and 1
file contained a closing summary (DHHS 222) which was completed outside of the
required timeframe.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim 8/17/2021, CAP approved 8/26/2021
FOM 722-06B FAMILY TEAM MEETING
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case Plan (ISP)
- within 30 calendar days before the case plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption At least three business days
prior to a planned change of placement or no later than three
business days after an unplanned placement change.
8

Case Closure Within 30 calendar days before the case closure
date or one business day after unplanned court ordered
dismissal.
Documentation The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, is
used to capture family demographics, FTM logistical
information, needs, strengths, action steps, safety concerns and
the safety plan, and any recommendations made for the family
during the FTM. The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be
completed for every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in MiSACWIS
using the FTM hyperlink within 7 business days of the FTM.
7 of 12 applicable case files reviewed did not contain documentation that either all
required FTMs were held and/or that the applicable documentation was not
completed/uploaded.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim 8/17/2021, CAP approved 8/26/2021
FOM 722-08 ONGOING CASE SERVICE PLANS - AGENCY SIGNATURES
SUPERVISOR APPROVAL
The supervisor must review and approve the service plan within
14 calendar days of the report date.
1 of 12 applicable case files reviewed contained 1 initial service plan which was not
approved within 14 days.
FOM 722-08A ONGOING CASE SERVICE PLANS - AGENCY SIGNATURES
Prior to finalizing, the caseworker and supervisor must review
the case service plan and all linked assessments and treatment
plans during a face-to-face meeting. Case service plan review
may occur during monthly case consultation (supervision).
The supervisor must review and approve the service plan within
14 calendar days of the report date.
1 of 12 applicable case files reviewed contained 1 updated service plan which was
not approved within 14 days.
FOM 722-08D TREATMENT PLANS - AGREEMENT AND SIGNATURES
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain
signatures from the following individuals, as applicable:
 Caseworker
 Supervisor
9

 Second line supervisor, when siblings in care are placed
apart
 Parents who are a member of a participating household.
 Youth ages 14 and older.
 Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated court-
ordered caregivers.
Parents/legal guardians, youth, and caregivers must check yes
or no for the following when signing the treatment plan:
 I have participated in the development of the Case
Service Plan and the Parent Agency Treatment Plan.
 I agree with the Case Service Plan and Parent Agency
Treatment Plan.
 I have been provided a copy of the Case Service Plan
and Parent Agency Treatment Plan to review, and I will
have the opportunity to express my disagreement with
the Case Service Plan and Parent Agency Treatment
Plan when the information is presented to court.
Note: If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to sign the
treatment plan, the caseworker must identify, and document
actions needed to secure the parent’s and/or youth’s
participation in service planning and compliance with the
treatment plan.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the electronic
case record within 30 days of the report date.
5 of 12 applicable case files reviewed did not contain all required signatures
obtained within the timeframe identified within the policy.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED previously cited as FOM 722-08C
Interim 8/17/2021, CAP approved 8/26/2021
FOM 722-08E FOSTER CARE/JUVENILE JUSTICE ACTION SUMMARY
The DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary is
used to document specific administrative actions or changes in
a case, including: • Child fatality. • Change in caseworker or
organization. • Change in parent contact information. • Foster
care transfer to adoption. • Change in placement. • Temporary
break from placement. • Program or case closing.
COMPLETION REQUIREMENTS The caseworker must
complete the DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action
Summary and upload to MiSACWIS within the timeframe
required for the specified action/change.
10

Placement Change - Prior to a planned placement change, or
within three business days of an emergency placement change.
Foster Care/ Juvenile Justice Program/Case Closure -
Within three business days of foster care and/or juvenile justice
program/case closure.
Caseworker/ Organization Change - Within three business
days of change in caseworker and/or organization.
3 of 15 applicable case files reviewed either did not contain required action
summaries or contained the document that was not completed within the required
timeframe.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim 8/17/2021, CAP approved 8/26/2021
FOM 801-03 MEDICAL PASSPORT
For each child in foster care the supervising agency must
maintain a medical passport. Per MCL 722.954c.
For children entering foster care, the initial medical passport
must be provided within two weeks of the child/youth's
placement date to the following
 Foster care provider.
 Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC) youth/young
adult re-entering foster care.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
 Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary
court ward.
- Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
- At reunification. Subsequent medical passports are not
required after reunification.
 The child’s foster care provider:
- At or prior to each placement.
- Quarterly.
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
Each foster care caseworker who transfers a child's medical
passport to another caseworker must sign and date the medical
passport verifying that s/he has sought and obtained the
11

necessary information under law and Michigan Department of
Health and Human Services (MDHHS) policy.
Receipt of the medical passport by the above listed parties is
documented in MiSACWIS by uploading the signed and dated
signature page into the Health Profile section.
4 of 9 applicable case files reviewed did not contain all medical passports required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim 8/17/2021, CAP approved 8/26/2021
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 When reviewing and endorsing documents from the lending agency, utilize a
uniform way of documenting the date reviewed and by whom the documents
were reviewed.
 Ensure that documentation is uploaded in closed foster home file from the family
requesting closure.
 If the first aid training certificates do not print with current date, foster parent
should be taking screen shots of the date they completed the re-certification for
verification rather than providing a text that it was completed.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
 A variance can be requested when education transcripts are delayed if
another form of education verification is obtained, in situations where filling a
position prior to receipt of the official transcripts is imperative.
 JCJ Cases: Utilizing a face sheet would make it easier to document/locate all
of the information required by rule 400.12404(6) & (7).
12

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
This CAP was submitted in response to interim inspection report dated 8/17/2021.
The CAP was approved on 8/26/2021 and the agency is not compliance with all
aspects of the CAP as evidenced by the number of repeat violation. It is noted that
there have been improvements in the number of incidents within each violation and
there has been progress toward improving compliance in these areas.
Chief Administrator Assessment – The chief administrator assessment was
discussed during the entrance meeting. The chief administrator identified areas of
non-compliance confirmed during the inspection. The chief administrator attributed
areas of repeat non-compliance to difficulty hiring qualified staff as well as staff
turnover resulting in learning curves.
Interviews – The staff members interviewed reported no concerns and stated overall
awareness of their responsibilities, policy/rule requirements, and methods of obtaining
clarification when needed.
VII. DCWL Analyst Concerns
No safety concerns identified
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
